technical-data.invention-title: Management of a configuration of a USB device
Gestion de la configuration d'un dispositif USB

description.heading: FIELD OF THE INVENTION
description.p: The present invention generally relates to the configuration management of devices. In particular, the invention is applicable to USB On-The-Go devices.
description.heading: RELATED ART
description.p: The approaches described in this section could be pursued, but are not necessarily approaches that have been previously conceived or pursued. Therefore, unless otherwise indicated herein, the approaches described in this section are not prior art to the claims in this application and are not admitted to be prior art by inclusion in this section.

The concept of On-The-Go (OTG) devices has been developed in addition to the specifications of the Universal Serial Bus (USB), originally designed as an interface between Personal Computers (PCs) and peripherals. In particular, the specification "On-The-Go and Embedded Host Supplement to the USB Revision 2.0 Specification" - Revision 2.0 - May 8, 2009 has been introduced to allow many devices, for example mobile phones or cameras, that are not PCs in the classic sense, to connect directly to peripherals, without requiring them to support the full range of USB peripherals.

Typically, in order to manage a USB interface, an OTG device comprises a control unit, said unit being generally implemented, in large part, in the form of a computer program, and an interface unit generally made up, in large part, of hardware components. The control unit requires the use of a high speed clock (typically 60 MHz) to work.

An OTG device is configured according notably to the configurations of devices connected to the USB interface and user actions. For example, the OTG device can act as a Host or as a Peripheral. Any changes in the configuration of devices connected to the USB interface and user actions must be processed by the OTG device to adapt its own configuration.

It is possible to detect such changes by measuring variations of physical characteristics on the USB interface. The OTG device reacts to a change in the configuration as explained hereinafter. On detection of a variation, the interface unit of the OTG device sends this information to the control unit. The control unit interprets the variation and gives instruction to the interface unit in writing flags or instructions via serial registers or by sending back commands to the interface unit.

This approach relies on a dialog between the control unit and the interface unit. A drawback of this solution is that it introduces latencies in the processing of a change of the configuration, since several entities must cooperate and the control unit is mainly implemented by the way of a software executed by a processor with limited resources. Moreover, it creates additional power consumption needs as the involvement of the control unit requires the use of a high speed clocks and processing power.
description.heading: SUMMARY
description.p: To address these needs, an embodiment relates to a method according to claim 1.

Thanks to an embodiment, upon detection of a change in the resistance value on the resistive line, the processing of this event is handled by the interface unit. In fact, the Interface unit manages the detection, the identification and the processing of this event. Contrary to the control unit generally implemented in the form of a computer program, the interface unit is generally made up in large part of hardware components. The processing of the event does not need anymore the involvement of the control unit. Thus, it is not anymore necessary to establish a bi-directional communication between the interface unit and the control unit, the interface unit being able to react almost instantly to a change of the configuration. It is then evident that latencies are reduced and power consumption can also be drastically scaled down.
This embodiment is also interoperable with existing devices, in particular USB On-The-Go devices, thus allowing a faster response time compared to known solutions.

The step /b/ can comprise any combination of the following steps:
adapting a power supply to the communication interface ; and/or,
adapting a clearance to charge from the communication interface; and/or;
adapting an authorization to check a session between the first device and said second device; and/or,
defining a role of the first device on the communication interface amongst Host or Peripheral.

The adapter allows, on the communication interface, the connection of the second device and a charger to supply power to the communication interface. The adapter is adapted to modify the resistance value of said resistive line according to a connection state of said charger to the adapter and according to the configurations of the first device and the second device.
The communication interface may be compliant with the Universal Serial Bus specifications.

The configuration unit can be capable of :
adapting a power supply to the communication interface of the first device; and/or,
adapting a clearance to charge from the communication interface of the first device ; and/or,
adapting an authorization on the first device to check a session between the first device and said second device ; and/or,
defining a role of the first device on the communication interface amongst Host or Peripheral.
The communication interface can be compliant with the Universal Serial Bus specifications.
A third aspect of an embodiment relates to a device comprising an Interface unit according to the second aspect of the invention.

A fourth aspect of an embodiment relates to a system comprising a first device according to the third aspect of an embodiment and at least one second device adapted to be linked to the first device via the communication interface.

The system can also comprise an adapter coupled in-between the first device and the second device. The adapter allows, on the communication interface, the connection of the second device and a charger to supply power to the communication interface. The adapter is adapted to modify the resistance value of said resistive line according to a connection state of said charger to the adapter and according to the configurations of the first device and the second device.
description.heading: BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF THE DRAWINGS
DESCRIPTION OF PREFERRED EMBODIMENTS
description.p: Expressions such as "comprise", "include", "incorporate", "contain", "is" and "have" are to be construed in a non-exclusive manner when interpreting the description and its associated claims, namely construed to allow for other items or components which are not explicitly defined also to be present. Reference to the singular is also to be construed in be a reference to the plural and vice versa.

According to a classical USB connection between two devices, one device is a Host and the other is a Peripheral. A Host is a physical entity acting as a host and generally includes a USB Host Controller. A Peripheral is a physical entity that performs a function.

An USB interface comprises up to five physical lines: ground GND, power supply VBUS, data link D+ and D-, resistance ID. The resistance ID line of an USB interface can be qualified as a resistivity line. Typically, an USB interface comprises a cable with up to five wires equipped at each end with a connector designed to be connected to a USB connector, with up to five contacts.

Considering the USB terminology, a Session is the period of time that VBUS is powered up. An A-device is a Host at the start of a session and supplies power to VBUS. A B-device is a Peripheral at the start of a session. During a session, the role of host can be transferred back and forth between the A-device and the B-device any number of times. The session ends when applications running on it have completed.

An OTG device is a portable device that uses an USB connector to operate sometimes as a Host and sometimes as a Peripheral. Consequently, OTG devices can be attached to each other. For example, a mobile phone is a Peripheral when it is connected via a removable USB cable to a computer acting as a Host. The same mobile phone is a Host for an USB storage key or a printer acting as Peripherals.

Referring now to figure 1, there is shown therein a block diagram of an OTG device 10 according to an aspect of an embodiment, connected via a first USB interface 15 to an Accessory Charging Adapter (ACA) device 14. By way of an example, the OTG device 10 can be a mobile phone, a personal assistant, an embedded device...

The features and the behaviour of ACA Devices are detailed in the chapter 6 of the USB specification "Battery Charging Specification" - Revision 1.1 - April 15, 2009. Also this document generally deals with charging and/or powering up from dedicated chargers, hosts, hubs and charging downstream ports.

In particular, the ACA device 14 is a USB device allowing the connection to the first USB interface 15 of:
a charger via an input 16 ; and
a USB accessory via a second USB interface 17.

The input 16 might be a USB interface or any another kind of interface, for example a co-axial connector to accommodate the output of a charger plugged into an electrical outlet. The ACA device 14 supplies power, through the charger when the former is connected to the input 16, on the VBUS line of the first USB interface 15 and the second USB interface 17. It has also to be pointed out that data transfers between the OTG device and the accessory are maintained, in a transparent manner independently of the presence of the ACA device.

The OTG device 10 comprises a control unit 12, said unit being generally implemented, in large part, in the form of a computer program, and an interface unit 13 is generally made up in large part of hardware components. Said control unit 12 and said interface unit 13 are coupled via an interface 16. The control unit 12 requires the use of a high speed clock (typically 60 MHz) to work.

The OTG device must adapt its configuration for the first USB interface following a change of configuration. For example, if the OTG device was acting as a Host and a charger was present (configuration (d)), only the ACA device 14 was providing power to the VBUS line of the first USB interface 15. On removal of the charger (configuration (a)), the OTG device must provide power to the VBUS line of the first USB interface 15.

In the description above, the architecture of the OTG device 10 is based on two different chips respectively for the control unit 12 and for the interface unit 13 linked with the interface 16. However, it will be understood by those skilled in the art that various other modifications may be made, and equivalents may be substituted, without departing from the true scope of the present invention. In particular, the control unit 12 and the interface unit 13 could be grouped for example on one chip.

In one embodiment, the logic blocks 22 are implemented using combinatorial logic blocks and/or logic circuits and/or truth tables. Such logic blocks 22 are efficient since they are characterized by their low-latency, their speed and their very low power consumption, no clock or active component being involved. Following the detection of a change of the configuration, the interface unit 13 transmits this information to the controller unit 12 via the interface 16.
Referring now to the figure 2, there is shown therein a flow chart illustrating steps of a method to process a change of the configuration, according to an aspect of an embodiment.
Initially, the OTG device is in a first configuration (-a-, -b-, -c-, -d- or -e-) corresponding to a given first value of the resistance R of the Resistance ID line of the first USB interface 15.
In a first step 110, the interface unit 13 detects a value change of the resistance value R on the Resistance ID line of the first USB interface 15.
In a second step 120, the interface unit 13 processes the change of the resistance R to configure the OTG device.

In particular, the OTG device can be configured to:
supply or not power to the VBUS line of the first interface 15; and/or,
enable or not charging from or to the VBUS line of the first interface 15; and/or
check if the session is valid or not.

While there has been illustrated and described what are presently considered to be the preferred embodiments, it will be understood by those skilled in the art that various other modifications may be made, and equivalents may be substituted, without departing from the true scope of the present invention. Additionally, many modifications may be made to adapt a particular situation to the teachings of the present invention without departing from the central inventive concept described herein. Furthermore, an embodiment of the present invention may not include all of the features described above. Therefore, it is intended that the present invention not be limited to the particular embodiments disclosed, but that the invention include all embodiments falling within the scope of the appended claims.
It is stipulated that the reference signs in the claims do not limit the scope of the claims, but are merely inserted to enhance the legibility of the claims.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1,
wobei der Schritt b) einen Schritt des Anpassens einer Stromversorgung an die Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15) aufweist.

Verfahren nach einem der Ansprüche 1 bis 2,
wobei der Schritt b) einen Schritt des Anpassens einer Freigabe aufweist, um von der Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15) zu laden.

Verfahren nach einem der Ansprüche 1 bis 3,
wobei der Schritt b) einen Schritt des Anpassens einer Autorisierung aufweist, um eine Sitzung zwischen der ersten Vorrichtung und der zweiten Vorrichtung zu prüfen.

Verfahren nach einem der Ansprüche 1 bis 4,
wobei der Schritt b) einen Schritt des Definierens einer Funktion der ersten Vorrichtung auf der Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15) zwischen Host- und Peripheriegerät aufweist.

Verfahren nach einem der vorhergehenden Ansprüche,
wobei die Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15) mit den Anforderungen des Universal Serial Bus konform ist.

Schnittstelleneinheit (13), welche in einer ersten Vorrichtung eine Steuerentität und eine Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15), welche geeignet ist, die erste Vorrichtung mit mindestens einer zweiten Vorrichtung zu verbinden, aufweist, wobei die Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15) mindestens einen ohmschen Leiter (ID) mit einem Widerstandswert (R) aufweist, wobei der Widerstandswert der Schnittstelleneinheit (13) erlaubt eine Konfiguration der zweiten Vorrichtung zu identifizieren,
dadurch gekennzeichnet,
dass die Schnittstelleneinheit aufweist: - eine Konfigurationsänderungsdetektionseinheit (210), welche im Stande ist, eine Änderung des Widerstandswerts auf dem ohmschen Leiter zu detektieren; - einer Konfigurationseinheit (220), welche im Stande ist, die Änderung des Widerstandswert zu verarbeiten, um die Konfiguration der ersten Vorrichtung (10) entsprechend der Konfiguration der zweiten Vorrichtung anzupassen, wobei ein Adapter (14) zwischen der ersten Vorrichtung und der zweiten Vorrichtung dazwischen gekoppelt ist, wobei der Adapter (14), auf der Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15), die Verbindung zwischen der zweiten Vorrichtung und einem Ladegerät ermöglicht um die Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15) mit Strom zu versorgen, wobei der Adapter (14) ausgebildet ist, den Widerstandswert des ohmschen Leiters entsprechend zu einem Verbindungszustand des Ladegeräts mit dem Adapter (14) und entsprechend der Konfiguration der ersten Vorrichtung (10) und der zweiten Vorrichtung zu modifizieren.

Schnittstelleneinheit nach Anspruch 7,
wobei die Konfigurationseinheit (220) im Stande ist, eine Stromversorgung für die Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15) der ersten Vorrichtung (10) anzupassen.

Schnittstelleneinheit nach einem der Ansprüche 7 bis 8,
wobei die Konfigurationseinheit (220) im Stande ist, eine Freigabe anzupassen, um von der Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15) der ersten Vorrichtung (10) zu laden.

Schnittstelleneinheit nach einem der Ansprüche 7 bis 9,
wobei die Konfigurationseinheit (220) im Stande ist, eine Autorisierung auf der ersten Vorrichtung (10) anzupassen, um eine Session zwischen der ersten Vorrichtung und der zweiten Vorrichtung zu prüfen.

Schnittstelleneinheit nach einem der Ansprüche 7 bis 10,
wobei die Konfigurationseinheit (220) im Stande ist, eine Funktion der ersten Vorrichtung (10) auf der Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15) zwischen Host- und Peripheriegerät zu definieren.

Schnittstelleneinheit nach einem der Ansprüche 7 bis 11,
wobei die Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15) mit den Anforderungen des Universal Serial Bus konform ist.
Vorrichtung mit einer Schnittstelleneinheit (13) nach einem der Ansprüche 7 bis 12.

System mit einer ersten Vorrichtung nach Anspruch 13,
mit mindestens einer zweiten Vorrichtung, welche ausgebildet ist, mit der ersten Vorrichtung (10) über eine Kommunikationsschnittstelle (15) verbunden zu werden, und einem Adapter (14), welcher zwischen der ersten Vorrichtung und der zweiten Vorrichtung dazwischen gekoppelt ist.
Method according to claim 1, wherein the step /b/ comprises a step of adapting a power supply to the communication interface (15).
Method according to any of claims 1 to 2, wherein the step /b/ comprises a step of adapting a clearance to charge from the communication interface (15).
Method according to any of claims 1 to 3, wherein the step /b/ comprises a step of adapting an authorization to check a session between the first device and said second device.
Method according to any of claims 1 to 4, wherein the step /b/ comprises a step of defining a role of the first device on the communication interface (15) amongst Host or Peripheral.
Method according to any of the preceding claims, wherein the communication interface (15) is compliant with the Universal Serial Bus specifications.

Interface unit (13) in a first device comprising a control entity and a communication interface (15) able to link said first device to at least one second device, the communication interface (15) comprising at least one resistive line (ID) having a resistance value (R), said resistance value allowing the interface unit (13) to identify a configuration of the second device, characterized in that said interface unit comprises : • a configuration change detection unit (210) capable of detecting a change of the resistance value on the resistive line; • a configuration unit (220) capable of processing said change of the resistance value to adapt the configuration of the first device (10) according to the configuration of the second device, wherein an adapter (14) is coupled in-between the first device and the second device, the adapter (14) allowing, on the communication interface (15), the connection of the second device and a charger to supply power to the communication interface (15), the adapter (14) being adapted to modify the resistance value of said resistive line according to a connection state of said charger to the adapter (14) and according to the configurations of the first device (10) and the second device.
Interface unit according to claim 7, wherein the configuration unit (220) is capable of adapting a power supply to the communication interface (15) of the first device (10).
Interface unit according to any of claims 7 to 8 wherein the configuration unit (220) is capable of adapting a clearance to charge from the communication interface (15) of the first device (10).

Interface unit according to any of claims 7 to 9, wherein the configuration unit (220) is capable of adapting an authorization on the first device (10) to check a session between the first device and said second device.

Interface unit according to any of claims 7 to 10, wherein the configuration unit (220) is capable of defining a role of the first device (10) on the communication interface (15) amongst Host or Peripheral.
Interface unit according to any of claims 7 to 11, wherein the communication interface (15) is compliant with the Universal Serial Bus specifications.
Device comprising an Interface unit (13) according to any of claims 7 to 12.

System comprising a first device according to claim 13, at least one second device adapted to be linked to the first device (10) via the communication interface (15), and an adapter (14) coupled in-between the first device and the second device.
Procédé selon la revendication 1, dans lequel l'étape /b/ comprend une étape d'adaptation d'une alimentation en énergie à l'interface de communication (15).
Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications 1 et 2, dans lequel l'étape /b/ comprend une étape d'adaptation d'une autorisation de charger en provenance de l'interface de communication (15).

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications 1 à 3, dans lequel l'étape /b/ comprend une étape d'adaptation d'une autorisation de vérifier une session entre le premier dispositif et ledit deuxième dispositif.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications 1 à 4, dans lequel l'étape /b/ comprend une étape de définition d'un rôle du premier dispositif au niveau de l'interface de communication (15), entre dispositif Hôte ou dispositif Périphérique.
Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel l'interface de communication (15) est en conformité avec les spécifications USB (bus série universel).

Unité d'interface (13) dans un premier dispositif comprenant une entité de commande et une interface de communication (15) capable de relier ledit premier dispositif à au moins un deuxième dispositif, l'interface de communication (15) comprenant au moins une ligne résistive (ID) ayant une valeur de résistance (R), ladite valeur de résistance permettant à l'unité d'interface (13) d'identifier une configuration du deuxième dispositif, caractérisée en ce que ladite unité d'interface comprend : - une unité de détection de changement de configuration (210) capable de détecter un changement de la valeur de la résistance au niveau de la ligne résistive ; - une unité de configuration (220) capable de traiter ledit changement de la valeur de résistance pour adapter la configuration du premier dispositif (10) en fonction de la configuration du deuxième dispositif, dans laquelle un adaptateur (14) est couplé de manière intermédiaire entre le premier dispositif et le deuxième dispositif, l'adaptateur (14) permettant, au niveau de l'interface de communication, la connexion du deuxième dispositif et d'un chargeur pour fournir une alimentation à l'interface de communication (15), l'adaptateur (14) étant apte à modifier la valeur de la résistance de ladite ligne résistive en fonction d'un état de connexion dudit chargeur à l'adaptateur (14) et en fonction des configurations du premier dispositif (10) et du deuxième dispositif.

Unité d'interface selon la revendication 7, dans laquelle l'unité de configuration (220) est capable d'adapter une alimentation en énergie à l'interface de communication (15) du premier dispositif (10).

Unité d'interface selon l'une quelconque des revendications 7 et 8, dans laquelle l'unité de configuration (220) est capable d'adapter une autorisation de charger en provenance de l'interface de communication (15) du premier dispositif (10).

Unité d'interface selon l'une quelconque des revendications 7 à 9, dans laquelle l'unité de configuration (220) est capable d'adapter une autorisation, au niveau du premier dispositif (10), de vérifier une session entre le premier dispositif et ledit deuxième dispositif.

Unité d'interface selon l'une quelconque des revendications 7 à 10, dans laquelle l'unité de configuration (220) est capable de définir un rôle du premier dispositif (10) au niveau de l'interface de communication (15), entre dispositif Hôte ou dispositif Périphérique.
Unité d'interface selon l'une quelconque des revendications 7 à 11, dans laquelle l'interface de communication (15) est en conformité avec les spécifications USB (bus série universel).
Dispositif comprenant une unité d'interface (13) selon l'une quelconque des revendications 7 à 12.

Système comprenant un premier dispositif selon la revendication 13, au moins un deuxième dispositif apte à être relié au premier dispositif (10) par l'intermédiaire de l'interface de communication (15), et un adaptateur (14) couplé de manière intermédiaire entre le premier dispositif et le deuxième dispositif.
